{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3601489,"name":"Michelle Banas","username":"Notquitebananas","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/notquitebananas/{size}/255355_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-23T16:40:52.067Z","cooked":"

R707 was updated this season to allow RFID or NFC systems used exclusively within the robot. Did anyone take advantage of this? If so, what did you use it for?

Honestly just curious because I was having trouble coming up with a good reason to use RFID inside the robot.

I think I remember someone bringing up battery tracking in the original update thread. That‚Äôs not a bad idea, but is the robot using this data at all?

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2025-04-23T16:50:53.991Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":593,"readers_count":592,"score":243.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":500281,"topic_slug":"r707-rfid-update-did-anyone-use-it","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":8}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":34970,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/r707-rfid-update-did-anyone-use-it/500281/5","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":7},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":8,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3601505,"name":"","username":"mstatistics","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mstatistics/{size}/267172_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-23T16:51:27.415Z","cooked":"

5892 Programmer here,
NFC battery tracking was my little project. The plan was to use battery tracking as a way to simplify battery selection for a match, while preventing issues like reuse. Other solutions like 6328‚Äôs use qr codes, but NFC allows us to store data on the battery itself. This allows us to store a history of usage, along with a running total of ah used. The data is accessible either through robot logs or scanning with a phone. No app is required on android, but IOS needs an NFC app to read the text on the tag. Everything is done, and it works on a roboRIO, but we didn‚Äôt end up running it this season because there wasn‚Äôt any training for electrical and I had some driver issues running it on a copossessor (I found that it would cause too many loop overrunes on a rio). Once I get those issues figured out I‚Äôll make a blog post on our open alliance.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2025-04-23T21:44:53.195Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":590,"readers_count":589,"score":233.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":500281,"topic_slug":"r707-rfid-update-did-anyone-use-it","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":6}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":62510,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"5892 Programming Lead"},"post_url":"/t/r707-rfid-update-did-anyone-use-it/500281/6","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":6}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":6,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3601958,"name":"Brett B Bonner","username":"bbonner","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bbonner/{size}/155176_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-23T22:28:09.770Z","cooked":"

I‚Äôll just add that from a 6328 perspective, we really like having battery tracking data. The previous few years we‚Äôve logged which battery is in use on the robot using a QR- or bar-code scanner. This lets us correlate any power-related performance issues against a specific battery (though this hasn‚Äôt been an issue in practice, it‚Äôs always possible) and gather interesting statistics through season-long log analysis. Positioning the scanner was always a little challenging, though.

That said, we didn‚Äôt end up doing it this year. The RFID rule update was appreciated and we purchased some simple RFID readers and battery-appropriate RFID stickers (that we could program using a phone), with the goal of a direct-to-Rio RFID reader. In the end we did not end up finishing this project because other things took priority.

We didn‚Äôt use the QR scanner this year - even if we‚Äôd mounted it (which we hadn‚Äôt) we would have ended up pulling it off for weight.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2025-04-23T22:28:09.770Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":443,"readers_count":442,"score":123.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":500281,"topic_slug":"r707-rfid-update-did-anyone-use-it","display_username":"Brett B Bonner","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":48574,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"6328 Mentor - Electrical/Controls"},"post_url":"/t/r707-rfid-update-did-anyone-use-it/500281/7","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3603353,"name":"Mykah","username":"ExploitSage","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/exploitsage/{size}/179189_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-25T02:54:26.663Z","cooked":"

Just a hypothetical idea, but modular subsystems. Could be for swapping to different subsystems similar to what you see in FLL, but more likely in FRC it would be for spares.

So lets say you have two assemblies of the same subsystem but with slightly different characteristics/configurations like different CAN IDs, PIDF Constants due to slight manufacturing differences (friction amiright‚Ä¶), or substituted parts like one using a Talon SRX and the other a Spark Max in Brushed mode due to parts availability. Normally when you did the swap, you would then have to go into the code and swap out the variables (and more in the case of different vendor motor controllers‚Ä¶), typically commenting one (or more) block(s) of code and un-commenting another set that you had already written, and push the updated code, which adds a lot of potential for human error at the time of the swap, though more elegantly you could have a single variable you update to select between configs, but this still requires manual code changes/push which adds at least a little additional room for human error. Instead you could stick some kind of RFID Sticker, Tag, or similar to the subsystem and have a reader on the robot where the subsystem mounts that connects to the RoboRIO, and code the robot such that when the RIO starts up it reads the RFID tag and selects the values based on which tag it sees so when you do the swap there are no, potentially massive, code changes required.

Is it worth it? ehh. But a neat idea I‚Äôm sure someone would want to try, me thinks.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2025-04-25T02:57:48.729Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":318,"readers_count":317,"score":78.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":500281,"topic_slug":"r707-rfid-update-did-anyone-use-it","display_username":"Mykah","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":16897,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"She/Her üè≥Ô∏è‚Äç‚ößÔ∏è | 9153 | Programming and Electrical Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/r707-rfid-update-did-anyone-use-it/500281/8","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3603402,"name":"Chris Gerth","username":"gerthworm","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gerthworm/{size}/8072_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-25T04:26:45.323Z","cooked":"
Notquitebananas:

That‚Äôs not a bad idea, but is the robot using this data at all?

From what I‚Äôve discussed with people as ideas around this, no, the robot collects the data.

The goal is just to track metrics on which batteries were run when, for how long, with how much discharge, etc.

Offboard analysis of many matches over time would be needed to produce useful results from the data‚Ä¶ results, I assume, like ‚ÄúThat battery got used way too much, relegate it to demo duty‚Äù

Of note though: If you do know the battery‚Äôs internal model (OC voltage, resistance, whatever else) to a high degree of accuracy, it opens some doors to set current draw budgets that keep the battery operating just barely above brownout voltages. Easier said than done though - we had a decent flavor of this working back in 2016, but haven‚Äôt attempted to replicate it since.

image1280√ó1707 345 KB

So I am having something coming up. I am now making a battery tag reader with ESP32 and RC522 on CAN bus. Currently, I am waiting for parts and hope I could get it working in a week.

On the picture is a design concept of reader for KOP chassis. There will be two RC522 on each side of the antenna holder (green part) so battery could be installed in any direction.

Custom CAN sensor - some good progress Control System
